awd_titl_txt: CAREER: CDS&E: Protein Structure Prediction from Covalent Labeling Mass Spectrometry Data
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Prof. Steffen Lindert and his group at Ohio State University are working to significantly extend the capabilities of mass spectrometry (MS) from simply characterizing the composition of molecules (e.g. metabolites, proteins, small chemical molecules) to helping predict detailed structures (especially of proteins). This is achieved by chemically reacting accessible sites on a protein with specific chemical labels and subsequently using MS to discover which sites on the protein were labeled.  Prof. Lindert's "MS-Fold" software then infers the protein structure from this labeling information.  Given the importance of proteins in regulating the chemistry of life, better tools for probing protein structure supports better understanding of that chemistry in both healthy and diseased organisms.  To help convey these principles to a general audience, the Lindert group is also developing an MS-Fold version of the popular scientific video game Foldit.  This work aims to increase public scientific literacy, and to expand interest and engagement in STEM science and technology-related disciplines. The ultimate goal is to increase STEM participation, particularly of underrepresented groups, and to improve STEM education at the undergraduate and graduate level. 

Sophisticated mass spectrometry (MS) techniques in conjunction with covalently-labeled protein residues can yield important information about protein structure. However, easy and reliable translation of this information into accurate structural models remains particularly challenging. The overall goal of research in the Lindert lab is to develop advanced computational tools that can convert MS-generated covalent labeling data into protein structural models in an automated fashion. Specifically, the research objective is to develop and validate a software tool, termed "MS-Fold", that will allow data generated from covalent labeling MS studies (e.g. solvent-exposed protein residues) to be effectively used to guide protein structure prediction algorithms. MS-Fold is intended to provide the analytical biochemistry community with a user-friendly computational tool with which covalent labeling MS data can be integrated into high-resolution analysis of protein structure and macromolecular interactions. This in turn will dramatically improve interpretability of MS data, constituting a significant advance in the field of structural MS and providing new opportunities for investigators to extract useful information from results of advanced MS experiments. The educational objectives entail novel approaches to interdisciplinary training for complex, joint computational-experimental chemical methods.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Sophisticated mass spectrometry (MS) techniques in conjunction with covalently-labeled protein residues yield important information about protein structure. The structural information is derived from the fact that solvent-exposed residues get labeled preferentially whereas buried residues are protected from labeling. This data, however, is not sufficient to predict protein structure unambiguously, as it only provides information on the relative solvent exposure of certain residues. As such, at the beginning of our project, easy and reliable translation of this information into accurate structural models was impossible. The overall goal of the proposed project was to develop advanced computational tools that can convert MS-generated covalent labeling data into protein models in an automated fashion. Specifically, we proposed to develop and validate a software tool, termed “MS-Fold”, that would allow data generated from covalent labeling MS studies (e.g. solvent-exposed protein residues) to effectively guide protein structure prediction algorithms. The proposed work aimed to address the following main objectives: The theoretical development of MS-Fold, including conversion of MS data into quantitative software input, development of MS-specific scoring functions to create models showing exposure of MS-labeled residues and finally implementation of those methods into the protein structure prediction software Rosetta. Additionally, an MS-Fold version of the popular scientific video game Foldit was proposed to be developed to facilitate the outreach activities. The educational objective of the proposal was to develop novel educational concepts that address interdisciplinary student education and training needs of complex, joint computational-experimental chemical methods such as computational methods in MS.

 

All objectives of the original proposal were achieved over the last six years. We developed MS-Fold for hydroxyl radical, diethylpyrocarbonate (DEPC) and hydrogen-deuterium exchange (HDX) labeling. Data from these covalent labeling techniques was used to successfully improve tertiary protein structure prediction in Rosetta. All implemented code is open-source and freely available to the academic community. Tutorials for easy use have been published along with the algorithms. We subsequently developed improved versions of MS-Fold for hydroxyl radical and DEPC labeling that accounted for protein dynamics to improve protein structure prediction from covalent labeling mass spectrometry data. In addition to benchmarking the performance of MS-Fold to predict proteins of known structure using covalent labeling data, we successfully applied MS-Fold in a blind test (using hydroxyl radical protein footprinting (HRPF) data) to accurately predict a protein of unknown structure which was later confirmed by NMR data. Additionally, we performed a comprehensive investigation of the capability of different covalent labeling reagents to facilitate protein structure prediction. Based on these studies, we determined an optimal subset of residues to use when performing covalent labeling experiments to maximize the structure prediction capabilities of the covalent labeling data.

The educational goal of this CAREER project was to develop novel educational concepts that address interdisciplinary student education and training needs of complex, joint computational-experimental chemical methods such as computational methods in MS. The educational and outreach activities had broader impacts in terms of enhancing the educational infrastructure and helping to develop highly trained personnel impacting human resources. The ultimate goal to increase student participation, retention and graduation in STEM fields was achieved. As part of the project, we trained a total of eight graduate students (of which four have received a PhD degree and one student has graduated with an MS degree) and ten undergraduate students. We implemented a joint computational and experimental methods training program. An outreach lecture series targeting institutions serving groups that are traditionally underrepresented in science was organized. In addition to developing a Computational Biochemistry course with integrated MS modules, research projects appropriate for undergraduate students were aligned to MS-Fold. Finally, the MS-Fold version of the online video game Foldit (which is close to release to the players) will allow connection to the wider population in order to increase public scientific literacy, interest and engagement in STEM science and technology-related disciplines.

 


Last Modified: 03/07/2024
Modified by: Steffen Lindert
